author: Philip Khoo
title: Co-participation fund: adafund.io
description: Obtaining funding through the existing Project Catalyst funding model is slow and overbearing. How can we explore options to make it faster?

assessments.note: It is not clear this proposal improves distributed decision making, it appears to be attempting instead to bypass it.
assessments.reply: There is nothing to say that the experiment can't try other ways to distribute decision making - I believe that it can be encouraged. People are entitled to differing opinions.

assessments.note:
The idea to have a fund to fast-track small projects has merits. Also, the idea to delegate decision making power could be a way to scale the process. 
However, it is not clear how the side-treasury would actually decide about funding. Are we being asked to effectively trust you to grant the funds? How does the governance of adafund.io itself work? The proposal does not explain this.
Also, it is not clear why the stated problem needs to be solved in the first place. What would we lose if we don't?
This would represent a very conscious and deliberate effort by two very active members of the community to improve its processes.
A co-funding system for smaller proposals seems like a good idea to adress the funding of low-cost proposals at a lower entry barrier and integrate more creators and funders into the ecosystem.

The problem and solution description is reasonable and is within the scope of the challenge. The option of a new, more agile model for fundind of lower cost proposals and the possibility for the community to participate in it by voting with its own financial capital distributes decision making in Catalyst.

Experimenting with new fundind models is a positive thing and can have a positive impact for Catalyst and the challenge. Due to the relatively low budget set for the proposals, the tendency is the small number of people to participate as co-funders, which considerably limits the potential impact on the distribution of decision making in the next 2 Funds.

Although the proposal states a real Project Catalyst problem, I do not think that it is in accordance with the idea of the challenge. I do not see how making the funding faster will help the distribution decision making.
It's important to notice, though, that this is a good idea and it should be better explored in another challenge.
assessments.reply: I beleive that this assessment contraditcs themself in their assessment. 'Real problem', faster decition making creating more distrabution. We belevie that it is in the correct challenge.

assessments.note: It is very hard to map this proposal to "distributed decision making". As this is an experiment to improve the funding method for catalyst, it might fit the guiding question "How can we ensure that the Catalyst process keeps iterating to improve?" but is a very far strech.
assessments.reply: The proposal directly addresses: improving decision-making processes and Community participation parts of the challenge.

assessments.note:
Implementing alternative funding structures is an interesting idea. The proposal effectively addresses the challenge and could be useful in discovering the best methods through an iterative, trial and error approach. 
The proposal could better explain the connection between alternative funding models and DDM. It should be very clear for voters.
This is attempting to change the economics of funding, the proposer does not provide any evidence they have experience  in this area.
assessments.reply: It could be argued that no one has experience to work on this. There is nothing in the experiment to determine if the current 'economics of funding' is the 'right' or 'only' way. We are exploring the bounds of alternatives.

assessments.note: The proposers already delivered something in the past. One point deducted because I'm afraid that running a mini-catalyst needs more than just a website.

Given the proposers and the scope of the proposal itself it's clear that the proposal will be implemented successfully. The level of success of the initiative as a whole is dependant on factors outside of the control of the proposers, thus it's level of overall success isn't completely guaranteed. However it's a risk well worth taking as it could potentially open up a new avenue of funding and free up Project Catalyst from proposals potentially better served by an alternative mechanism of funding.

While the team obviously has some experience i web design and within the cardano ecosystem, the milestones lack a concrete timeframe of the implementation and some details on the plan on how to build up the system. Yet, given the experience of the team it is likely that the proposal will be implemented.

The team has two members who are involved in the Catalyst community, they participate as CAs and are involved in the development of some projects and implementations for improvements in Catalyst, some of these implementations have already been delivered, such as  documentation, and other projects are under development, such as the Catalyst Project Landing Page and the CA tool.

The budget described is reasonable and has details on the allocation of resources.

Some aspects of the plan need to be further clarified. If there is a high demand for people requesting funds, it may be necessary to establish some priority model for the distribution of the Funds (possibly the first ones will be prioritized by the model that was presented and this ends up benefiting people with prior knowledge. How to maintain equal conditions) in that case?

In addition, how will the funds be managed? We don't have smart contracts yet. Will the proposers be in charge of allocating resources?

If the totality of the funds is not distributed, the remaining amount would be returned to the treasury or passed on to another proposal. There is no clarity on this point. What would define if the funds would be returned or passed on to bounties in the Landing Page proposal?

There is a conflict of interest in this case, as the team is involved in the Landing Page proposal and could benefit from these additional resources. I believe that this situation needs to be better defined, since approving such a loophole can give freedom to other proposals to redistribute unused resources in an arbitrary way.
assessments.reply:
The distribution of unused funds is stated in the proposal - so fully transparent. We are not sure if there is a mechanism to return funds to the treasury. It can be for the voters to decide if the funds being used for another associated proposal (ie as bounties given to community members to do develop on the community site is acceptable). 

I agree that some things need further thinking and clarification. However not everything needs to be decided at the time of proposal.

assessments.note:
One thing that catch my attention is the thought that if this scale, how faster it would really be compared with the actual project, once you need a time to analyze every proposal and help them to improve them, by giving advises if necessary.
However, it is feasible, since the team members are assiduous in the community and have experience in the job.
Maybe if you use some tool like the one developed by Vic (CA-tool, for example), you could allocate an even number of people to each project, which could make them focus and accelerate the whole process.
Another point to analyze is if the proposals submitted into this platform would be feasible with $250, since the other half is conditionate to results.
assessments.reply: The proposal is for a test of an idea. There is no need to consider it at any more scale than what is considered in the proposal.

assessments.note: Caralyst has established various mechanism to ensure fair funding and prevent misuse. An existing platform was used to keep the scope of the project in check. The risk of misuse of the proposed solution seems pretty high and this troubles me. Phil and Victor have proven to provide solutions that offer significant added value. Combined with my doubts, I am at 4 points.

The proposers have the experience to implement the proposal successfully. Having participated in the Discord server for a few months, the two proposers are everywhere. They are responsible for many useful tools already in place, and this offers a heightened sense of confidence that the proposal will be successful.

It is not discussed how this proposal addresses the challenge. A key risk of proposers funding their own proposal is suggested to mitigate by delaying partial payment. This does not however actually address this issue. The solution will just allow small amount to be funded if you match with your own funding (which you get back) and meet milestones you set for your self, which could be easily gamed.
The whole governance part is missing. Who effectively would decide about funding? How and by whom are the deciders chosen? What would be the criteria upon which funding is granted or denied?

I would have liked to see a little more details on how the selection process would work, but other than that I haven't found anything lacking, perhaps an estimated start date but I'm guessing it could start as soon funds are received.

The description on how the decision making mechanism is compromised and how it differs from Project catalyst and on how the success is audited is only described vaguely, making it difficult to assess how feasible it is.

There is clarity in the problem and the solution presented. The proposal is in line with the challenge.

There is a budget breakdown, details about the team's experience. A 3-month timeline for delivery has been defined and objective milestones have been presented, but there is no clear definition of how long each stage described in the milestones will last.
assessments.reply: The advisor argues that the propsal is not feasible because it's not auditable, but there are different criteria and should be assessed separately.

assessments.note:
There is no KPI or metrics to analyze in this proposal. But I understand that the success of the project would be measured by the time between the submit of a proposal and the actual funding of the project. Therefore, I think the proposal would be more complete if you add something like this in the metrics.
Besides that, the idea must be scalable, it must aggregate enough people to vote and help the co-funding in order to give confidence in the decision of funding and avoid frauds.
Budget breakdown and milestones are provided. KPIs are not povided, but with the nature of the proposal, the funded proposals are a natural fit.

The proposal provides milestones, indicators, and a timeline that make it easy to audit. It is clear that the proposers have thought through some potential challenges and offer mitigation measures. Voters can easily see the exact elements that are being proposed in a simple and straight forward manner. 

More detail could be provided on how they got to the amount for the small funding pools. What is the likelihood that a project would only require such a minimal amount?

solution: Create a side treasure that explores different funding models. In this case, a co-funding model exploring funding for low cost proposals.
experience: The proposer & developer of community landing page and info-graphics in Fund3. CAs/vCAs since Fund3/4. Proposers of Community Tools.
